24462967.review:
What can I say about Ubermosh.

I've got it in the steam summersale.
It was kind of an impulse buy, like when you're in the
music store buying a heavy metal album from its cover art.

The soundtrack is superb. And while there are plenty of
games waiting in my backlog to be played, Ubermosh
just slided by those. I'm enjoying it as much as I'm bad
at it, and I'm enjoying it very much.

It's the sort of fast paced action you can put in between
longer games, or when you've got some minutes to spare. It 
has enough variation to keep you entertained. And challenged!

When I have been going at it with a class for about five times,
I switch to another. The differences between the classes give
you a change of approach to refuel your reflexes, when you
are trying the melee class the next time.

I've grown too old for bullet hell games.
Ubermosh has a hell of a lot of bullets flying around.
But it's the first time in a while I'm enjoying beeing in
the middle of a bullet armageddon. This may be 
because this is not quiet bullet hell game,
even though, well, bullets, everywhere.

Ubermosh had me at 
'cutting your enemies' bullets with your sword'

I'm just taking a break to have another go at 
trying to kill 150 enemies with their own
bullets. By cutting them in spreadshots.
And sending em back at them. 

If you are just even slightly interested in this 
game, you'll get a good impression of it in under 
two hours, so I'd recommend giving it a try. 
And refund it, if it's not your cup of tea. 

Happy bullet cutting!

24422063.review:
[h1]I love it to hate it[/h1]

[b]UBERMOSH[/b] is a small, interesting, frantic arcade game where you have to shoot an reflect bullets with your sword. And that's it. I just told you the whole idea of the game.

But that's not the problem. UBERMOSH is quite interesting having a unique soundtrack and art style as well is really interesting and challenging gameplay. Even though there's not much to do in the game [spoiler](got 100% of Achievements in 1.9 hours)[/spoiler] it's still fun to play. I really like games that require fast reflexes and decision making because UBERMOSH really succeeds in that.

Unfortunately the good things stop there. Even though UBERMOSH was fun to play despite the repetitive gameplay it had more flaws in the game mechanics than in the short amount of gameplay. The camera is way too close for you to react to anything that's a couple of meters away from you and the hitboxes and spawn points are glitchy... That's the real problem of the game. The enemy bullets will spawn in front of the gun. Not from the barrel of the gun which makes it very hard to predict when to reflect the bullets because you'll be already taking damage before you could even see the bullets. This combined with the extremely glitchy hitboxes makes the gameplay incredibly annoying.

Persoanlly I think that the game is super easy if you fix these problems which then leaves one question... Is the game flawed? Yes. Does it have potential? Yes. A lot. The mechanics are fun and the fast speed of the game makes it fun to play but just because the mechanics are glitchy and flawed there's really no reason to buy this game. If they would be refined UBERMOSH could be one of the best Arcade shooters of all time.

24225435.review:
UBERMOSH is quite a game, I could describe it as a some sort of arcade Sci-fi  monster hell in which the main character wields a sword that can deflect bullets and you can grab the enemy's pistols for your own use.
The main goal is to survive for 90 seconds, you would say that is easy piecy but it isn't, the game is really hard and unforgiving, at the beginning you will survive less than 30 seconds, but the more you play it you develop an strategy to finally do it.

The graphics and it's optimization is well made and it aims to its purpose, the controls are responsive without a doubt, the only way you are going to die is by your own hand.

But you may be question me: "IS THAT IT?" and i can answer you with a "Yes and No"

UBERMOSH has several mods to play which consist on the normal mode, a mode where you can use only your sword, another that you can use only your pistol and a difficult mod that you can use your sword and the most powerful gun but you can only get hit twice, besides that you can change the difficulty to hardboiled mode which is harder.

But by the time you establish your strategy you have pretty much defeated the game with all of its mods (or at least that's what happened to me), and I'm not saying that is poorly designed, [i] au contraire mon ami	[/i], the game is well done but at least for me the challenge lasted about 30 minutes until I decided to get all of the achievement.

At the end of my review I would say that UBERMOSH is quite an entertaining game made for people who likes challenges,  on relation to it's value you won't feel defrauded with what you get.

24199126.review:
TL; DR - Fun and fast-paced game where you use blade to cut bullet from robotic AK-47.

Great time-waster that takes place in a futuristic, cyber-punk reality where killing things is (legal) entertainment.

You play as some badass grill with a fergalicious sword that she can use to CUT BULLET by right clicking. 
You murder aliens and other humans to take their guns in order to murder more aliens and other humans.

Each gun has a different type of bullet, be it large and firing one at a time or small, spread, and firing three at a time. There is a total of four (maybe five, I'm 90% sure it's four.) gun types, one of which can only be acquired by killing the big aliens.
You'll be able to tell by the yellow blood.
This gun is the strongest, as it shoots the most BULLET at a time.

The main objective of the game is trying to kill as many enemies as possible before you take too many hits or run out of time.
Your weapon selection and weapon attributes can be changed with class mods, which can be selected before you start playing.

Warlock gives you the best gun right off the bat and doesn't let you change it. You can be hit three times.

Gunner removes your ability to use your sword, but makes all your weapons auto-fire, making them shoot while you hold down the mouse button. You can be hit four times.

Kensai removes your ability to use guns, leaving you to only using your sword. You can be hit six times.

There's also this thing where you can change your gamemode to "Hardboiled" which I'm assuming makes it harder but I personally haven't noticed any difference.

I reccomend.

すさまじいゲームスピードで展開する鬼畜死にゲー。

とにもかくにも強烈なアクをもったゲームバランスとなっている。
自分も敵も一撃死、攻撃を喰らい次第即死するゲームでジュワジュワ溶けていく
主人公が敵と違う点は、リスポーン・コアなるものをもっていて三回まで攻撃を食らってもよい(四回目で死ぬ)こと、薙刀で弾丸をはじけることのふたつだけである。

はっきり言って運ゲーもいいところで、画面外からいきなりスポーンしてきて避けられない弾をぶちかましてくる敵はいるし
どうせ一撃で死ぬので単発の銃は完全にハズレ扱いで、散弾を撃てる銃以外は持ち替えてしまうと事故る文字通りの地雷であり
薙刀も振れるレートが低すぎてやはり事故死しやすいという、とんでもないゲームバランスだが

その分リプレイがすぐにでき音楽もよく、死んだところで失うアイテムもない、死にゲーとしてそのあたりの必要な諸要素はきちんとしている。
この値段を考えれば非常に良い出来だろう。シンプルな死にゲーが好きなら、セールのときにどうだろうか？

24104361.review:
I realize everyone has there own opinions and preferences, but I seriously cannot understand how this game has a 90% positive rating from over 600 people. This is the kind of free flash game that you would see on Newgrounds.

One major problem is that the game is zoomed in so far that you cannot see what is happening around you. As you walk in any direction, you get even closer to that edge of the screen which gives you even less time to react when an enemy or projectile pops onto the screen. If you could see more of the game, you may be able to use a bit of strategy instead of just having swarms of enemies rush you from all sides with little to no notice before getting hit.

Also, there is no substance at all. You are in a bland arena with a few barriers scattered around and you can shoot or swing your sword. There are about 4 different guns, but they are all basically the same thing with the better ones shooting more projectiles at once. You basically just spam as many bullets as you can for 90 seconds and try to kill as many enemies as possible. It's best to spam bullets in all directions because you cannot see very far and if you do not kill the enemies that are approaching off screen, they will run you over from all sides.

I liked how the art style of the game looked and it sounded promising with all the positive reviews, but there is literally nothing to this game. There is no progression, almost no weapon variance, no levels, no story, no upgrades, there is literally no substance. I could understand if the game was still in early access and these things were going to be added, but it is not.

In it's current state I would not recommend this game to anyone.

24083484.review: Just discovered this gem. I fell in love instantly when I discovered there is no Pause feature. It was at that moment I said "Sweet Raptor Jebus, there is no pause... yes this is a REAL bullet hell game!!", as a Bullet Hell adict, I spit in the face of easy modes, save features, and such a silly thing like a pause button, there is no pause in the chaos and death known as True Bullet Hell gaming, don't you dare blink or itch your nose muhahah,it becomes a test of your own will and power over your own body and is a realm meant only for the relentless and hardcore. Indstrial metal thumps harder than Quake 2 tunes and drives the NON STOP violence. Life and Death is a supreme black and white factor in game, you survive by franticly avoiding bullet chaos, perfecting timing by repeling bullets, getting a good gun and trying to hold corners while at the same time avoiding picking up a worse one till it becomes too much and you bail. The art style is great as well. Luck, pure punishment, and a test of skill while making your own split second tactics, Yus, this game will give you Bullet Hell Zen, let go of the false self and simply be within the torrents of Bullets and Chaos. 10/10 Art style is epic as goat teeeets, real sweet stuff. Just wish it had a two player mode, or online co-op function.

23980518.review:
UBERMOSH is more fun than should be allowed for only $2. It does exactly what it sets out to do: "give you a shot of adrenaline in a couple of minutes." You run around and shoot/slice anybody else in the pit for up to 90 seconds. That's it...And it's perfect.

Guns feel appropriately powerful, the sound of your sword deflecting enemy bullets is satisfying, and each enemy you K.O. leaves a little puddle of success so you clearly know they're down. The colors of incoming enemy fire stand out from the background and enemies are highlighted by a bright ring at their feet, which is great because you'll be looking everywhere all at once. The action is challenging but not frustratingly difficult. Even if you fail, you can be back in a new round quickly. The short rounds give you incentive to get out there and brawl without the fear of losing progress.

I spent a [i]long[/i] time eyeing UBERMOSH, which is stupid considering its ridiculously low price tag and the fact that it's perpetually on sale. Don't make my mistakes. Buy UBERMOSH.

23915928.review:
"The colony provides for everything...except for violence..."

UBERMOSH is like a top-down Devil Daggers.  You appear in an arena and are tasked with surviving 90 seconds of relentless onslaught.  90 seconds isn't much, right?  And all of the enemies die in a single hit--how hard could this possibly be?

As it turns out, hard as fucking [i]nails[/i].  Set to a thrumming metal and techno soundtrack (which is easily one of the best things about UBERMOSH), you will die again and again and again.  Fortunately the game subscribes to Edmund McMillen's "Super Meat Boy" model, wherein dying happens quickly and restarts are virtually instantaneous.  This game doesn't want to waste your time--it just wants 90 seconds.

Depending on your class*, you may begin with a sword; use it to relieve an opponent of one of a handful of different firearms.  Some of these weapons are great.  Some aren't so great.  Fortunately (as I previously mentioned) enemies die as quickly as you.  Therefore the best weapons are those that allow you to spread death around fastest.  Within 30 seconds of a single game, you'll have access to every available weapon--pick the one that works best for you.

*[i]There are several unlockable classes that are fundamentally different takes on the same thing:  One can only use a sword, one starts with the best weapon, etc.  And each has a different number of allotted respawns.  They impact the game, but not in a radical way.[/i]

The game is stripped of all but the barest essentials--there's nary a plot, an economy, or an exposition.  UBERMOSH doesn't have time for those sorts of formalities.  And because of that, the game's a great shot of adrenaline whenever you've got more than a couple of minutes to stop and play it.

Who might like this game?  Anybody who wants a no-frills top-down shooter that's hard as hell.  People who love a soundtrack that makes you want to kill, crush, and destroy.  For those who played Devil Daggers and thought, "You know, I wish this game was remade as a twin-stick shooter."  For $1.99 this game is a solid deal; for $0.49--[i]the price of upgrading a burger to a goddamn cheeseburger[/i]--you'd be a fool to skip out on this game.   

PROS
+ Great Soundtrack
+ Super accessible drop-in/drop-out model 
+ Very challenging

CONS
- Lame Steam cards, emoticons, and wallpapers.  Seriously, the wallpapers are just black backgrounds with a circular shape and the emoticons are colored spurts.
- Weapons could use a little more variety

23670445.review:
It's a high-octane, heavy-metal-fuelled adrenaline surge. You start out tense, watching your timer tick down as you wait for the first enemy to appear, and then immediately you're frantically dodging and deflecting and firing wildly into a horde of... monsters? Robots? Cyborgs? The 8-bit graphics should be pretty simple to figure out; but honestly I've never had time to take a proper look -- I'm too busy trying to kill everything that moves.

It's a simple and straightforward game with no real catches or snares -- you fight for your life for 90 seconds or as long as you can hold out, and try to beat your score. You can modify your starting loadout/abilities (they're practically the same thing, which isn't a bad thing at all in a game like this -- it's super simple and intuitive), you can increase the difficulty further if you like, and there are a few entirely option badges to aim for if that's your thing. Again, the badges are simple and straightforward; but they're still going to require you to draw on different skillsets and strategies if you want to complete them.

For $2 you get a game which is *exactly* what it looks like on the tin, but still offers the depth that makes it worth coming back. This game isn't trying to be anything more than a fast, hard-hitting bullet hell/arena arcade game; but it works perfectly within that niche so if that's your niche as well then you'll get a good deal here.

23116256.review:
Estoy erecto ;---------->D

Ahora en serio es un juego alucinante para su precio. El gameplay e muy divertido y entretenido.

Lo basico del juego es lo siguiente:
Tienes una espada que devuelve las balas de los enemigos. Cuando matas a un enemigo este pierde su arma. Hay 4 modelos de armas. Cuando consigues la mejor que es como una escopeta que dispara muy amplio no cojes mas armas. Digo que es la mejor porque ademas de que el propio juego lo indica es la que mas balas dispara y la que mas amplio. Da igual lo pequeñas o debiles que parezcan las balas porque matan siempre y a mas de un enemigo.

Ahora entra lo complicado. Cuando tienes muchos enemigos tienes que decir si disparar o acuchillar. Disparar el arma te puede quitar a 4 o 5 enemigos cercanos pero no te permitira acuchillar en casi un segundo (creerme que es mucho). Si matas a alguien disparando creo que el tiempo de volver a disparar se reduce. CREO. Si escojes acuchillar devolveras las balas en un cono bastante amplio, casi 90º. Pero puede que no mates a tantos enemigos y si no matas a nadie te quedas rodeado por 10 enemigos que es morir.

El juego incuye unos cuantos retos como conseguir una puntuacion especifica con ciertas clases. Tambien tiene un modo hardcore que reinicia el juego. Aun no lo he probado pero seguramente actualize.

22777616.review:
[b] UBERMOSH [/b] è un gioco  arcade dove il vostro obiettivo sarà abbattere più mostri possibili e sopravvivere alla fine della partita. Prima che loro avranno la meglio su di voi.

Vi ritroverete in un arena,con una musica fantastica (che vi consiglio di sentire a tutto volume) e partirà una sessione di gioco frenetica,divertente e complessa.Complessa perché i mostri sono davvero veloci e dopo pochi colpi sarete morti,quindi all'inizio risulterà  difficile finché non prenderete la mano e vi abituerete alla velocità di gioco.

Secondo me si ritrova alcune pecche,ad esempio la visuale è un po' troppo zoomata e a volte i nemici appaiono dal nulla senza che voi riusciate a vederli in tempo,ma piano piano vi abituerete anche a questo continuando a tentare.La seconda pecca è la durata e la poca rigiocabilità,le sessioni di gioco sono molto corte se riusciste a vivere e purtroppo essendo solo un'arena,stessi personaggi e stesso sistema,dopo averlo finito non lo toccherete più,non avendo altro da fare,anche se il gioco contiene pure una modalità più difficile chiamata Hardboiled che vi darà magari qualche altra ora di gioco,se avete la pazienza di rigiocarlo.

La cosa buona è che se siete dei tipi a cui piace finire i giochi al 100% è il gioco perfetto. Essendo veloce e complesso,è un ottimo gioco da completare e vi regalerà stress e soddisfazioni.

Beh che dire? Preso in offerta  49 centesimi e sono stati soldi spesi bene,durante i saldi lo troverete spesso a poco e vi consiglio di dargli un'occhiata,anche se corto saranno 2 orette di puro rage e frenesia.

FRE-NÉ-TI-CO

Ubermosh consiste em partidas de (até) 90 segundos nos Desertos de Ultakaar, fora da Colônia que: "...provides us everything, except for violence."

O jogo tem um ritmo muito rápido, você vai ter que se acostumar com sua velocidade e comandos, mas a vontade é de jogar de novo e de novo pra bater seu placar, melhorar o rank, ou alcançar as conquistas. Não se preocupe que nada faz mais parte desse game do que morrer. Só aperte play de novo!

A trilha sonora é uma marca do jogo, que traz batidas alucinantes que casam completamente com ele, vale a pena comprá-la junto.

E existe quem conseguiu bater todas as conquistas, e se acostumar com Ubermosh. Por isso existe: Ubermosh Black.

Have fun in the mosh pit ♥

21897634.review:
For a little over 2 dollars you can buy a candy bar or a soft drink from a store. However for the same price you can buy a pretty sweet game that goes by the name of Ubermosh.

Similar Games:
CS GO 2D and the Hotline Miami series are what I can think of right off the bat.

Gameplay: 
The rounds start off with a trickle of foes, you might even wonder where's the action? Well no worries, in around 10 seconds the screen will be filled with a deluge of pixel foes who wish nothing more than to delete your sorry ass from the arena. 
To combat these hordes of incoming foes you can choose 3 distinct classes, each with their own playstyle. The classes are Kensai, Gunner, and Warlock. 

The Kensai is the most durable of the three but is restricted to using the blade only. 
The Gunner has no defensive abilities besides dodging bullets, however she gains the ability to go full auto with her guns, like the saying goes, the best defense is a great offense.

 The Warlock gives you the best gun right off the bat and lets you swing your sword, sounds pretty OP right? It is, to a certain extent, but you only have 2 health (Although you can deflect bullets leading to a debate if the Warlock actually is less durable than the Gunner.) 

If you don't want to be restricted by class, running without a class is a good way to get into the flow for Ubermosh.

Pros:

Cheap
Faced paced action
Sense of satisfaction when you do well

Cons: 

Spawns are wonky sometimes
Can get repetitive with only one map
Gets frustrating if you force yourself too much

Would I recommend this game? Hell yes, for the low price of 2.19 it's definately worth it, although you may wish to buy Ubermosh Black instead for a similar price if you are willing to devote 1 more dollar to this kind of game :).

21695154.review:
There are only a few things that can be said for Ubermosh; almost none of them are negative. It's a simple game, really. You're thrown into an arena, tasked with killing as many enemies as you can, while simultaneously trying to last for the duration of the event. There are several guns, and a blade which allows you to cut enemy bullets, winging them back at the shooters. I can't level any worthwhile complaints at the mechanics of the game. If this was all that Ubermosh offered, it would be a solid - albeit, lackluster - game. However, I haven't touched on its best parts, yet.
At its core, Ubermosh is a frenzied bullet-hell shooter. It's arcade-y in all of the best ways - simple, clean, and addictive. But, this isn't what makes Ubermosh so much fun. No, it's the chaotic, electric-neon adrenaline rush the game manages to create. 
The soundtrack for Ubermosh fits the gameplay and visual style completely. The gritty, pounding electronic vibes blend perfectly to the frenzied tempo of pulsing laser weapons and slashing projectiles. Visually, Ubermosh conjures something akin to the neon-drenched arcades of Gibson's Sprawl Trilogy; it's a mix of static and pixelated splashes of vibrant color. 
Ubermosh is a simple game, yes. Simple enough that some might consider it a negative. However, it's a steal at $2 - well worth the price of admission. 

Ultimately, Ubermosh is an addictive, pulse-pounding pixelated frenzy of a game; it's a game with the look and sound of a cyberpunk dream, which delivers frantic combat. And, I can't help but recommend it.

21324559.review:
Übermosh is an intense ride through and through. You get 90 seconds to survive and take down as many gun-wielding alien goons as possible, and initially, you only get a sword. You bring a knife to a massive gunfight. Luckily your blade is capable of reflecting and splitting enemy fire and forcing them to eat their own bullets.

Graphically, the game is very simple, but effectively incredibly intense. You'll see classic pixel sprites and a constant smooth 60fps throughout. It's also incredibly color and plain fun to look at.

Gameplay wise, this game is a roller coaster. You get a few different classes to choose from, and each of which you'll have to master if you plan on 100% completing this game. No Class Mod has you start with a sword only, but allows you to pick up enemy guns, and you get 4 hits before you fall. Kensai allows use of only the sword, but you get six hits before game over. Gunner gives you a fully automatic gun at the cost of your sword and give you only three hits. The last and frankly best class is Warlock, which gives you use of the sword and the best gun in the game right out the gate. However, just two hits and you're down for the count. Completing this game requires you to get 150 points with each class, 200 points with any class seven times, surviving the full 90 seconds seven times, and attempting (but not beating) Hardboiled Mode. If you love games that are purely score-based and are easily motivated to beat your own high score, this game is tailor-made just for you and I guarantee you'll have hours of fun.. If you don't break your mouse. By the way, I do highly recommend using the keyboard and mouse over a controller. I personally find the twin-stick shooter controls awkward and troublesome. It works smoothly and everything, but it's simply not my cup of tea.

The music in this game is by far the best element, and the developer was smart to include the soundtrack as DLC. I can't really describe it well but I guarantee you could listen to it while fighting off an alien invasion and be pumped and focused the entire time.

I absolutely recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun, difficult time killer! It's hectic, fast-passed and difficult, so beginning gamers may have a tougher time, but give it a bit of practice and you'll have it completed in a matter of hours.

9/10

TL;DR

PROS:
- Incredibly fun
- Incredibly high replay value
- Best soundtrack on Steam. No joke.
- 100% completed very quickly if you're focused and skilled
- The badges and cards aren't bad either

CONS:
- Very high difficulty - not recommended for newer gamers
- May cost you a mouse or two if you're easily frustrated

21299465.review:
Having bought the game after 'A Kind Ale War' (Australian youtuber... watch him you) I knew what I was getting into and I can say that it does not dissapoint.

It is a simple game; you spawn on an alien planet with a sword and some Health. You deflect an aliens bullets back at him, kill it, take its gun and kill everything else until you die. Its simple but fun; and its gameplay is sploffing fantastic. There are a few modes, in one of which you spawn with the best gun in the game and you go on a rampage; another limits you to your sword (I love it) and another limits you to your gun.

There is a Hard mode for you suicidal folks out there which is not needed because the game is not easy, far from it. Not that its hard to learn, its just hard in general; you are going to need twitch skills to avoid jumpscaring damn Aliens coming out of the corner of your screen.

What about the problems? Well, there is one. One huge one. There is not enough content; as soon as you spawn and play for a Min or so (if you do not die) you have seen most of the content on display. I reccomend a few updates to the game to increase its content; new enemies, new maps (I wanna see a jungle damn you!), new weapons, new everything! This game has a fantastic OST and its gameplay is perfect, if it were to have more content it would be a fantastic game.

For now its a very good game in its own right, little bursts of gameplay for the lols every now and again (because the loading times are brilliant) are nice, but if you dont give me enough content to keep my intrested I will not stay intrested and I will go off to play a game with more substance.

I rate it a 8/10. Why not less because it has little content? Well, look at its price. Its great value, every pence you put towards this game will be rewarded with a good amount of content. Bang for your buck.

PS: You know that announcer at the start? I want to get that guy's voice in my life.

EDIT: After a few hours of writing this review, I not only discovered that the developer cannot change the game any more without adding entire DLC's or games, but I discovered that there is another version of Ubermosh. UBERMOSH: BLACK. Not only are the breasts on the main character improved but it has various other addons. I'll throw my money at it and see how it is.

21018517.review:
The colony provides us everything. Except for violence.

The gameplay is simple and fairly conventional. You run around and kill aliens with gun and sword, racking up as many kills as you can within a time limit. This game takes it to the next level with absolutely top notch presentation. The music is fantastic. The weapons are satisfying. There's no plot, but there's a hint of a setting that I find intriguing. I hope to see more.

There are a few classes, but they don't really change the gameplay significantly. Instead, I'd say they're better served as training tools. No class is the best all around, but you can learn from the weaknesses of the other classes and come back as a better player.

There are a few flaws. It's very easy to get stuck on the walls, and hits seem to my eye a split second before you actually see collision with enemy bullets. It took a bit of practice to get used to the timing with the sword for that reason, and it can be difficult to know why you died because there aren't any visual cues when you take your last hit.

Those are minor issues, though. This game, for its limited scope, is fantastic.

20879559.review:
Ubermosh is a top-down cyberpunk roguelike indie action game. The plot of the game is that you're in the distant future where there's no violence and your only rage-outlet is an arena filled with monsters. The point is to survive as long as you can with a sword and various guns, and that's easier said than done. 

In its current state Ubermosh is a really great game with an amazing soundtrack that begs you to come back for more. If you want to test your reflexes and hand eye coordination I would highly suggest this game. Buy the bundle, you won't be disappointed. 

I did a UI review which you can check out here: https://youtu.be/4WrfE-r5BEo

20875616.review:
Comme quoi, les recommendations Steam apportent des fois de vraies bonnes surprises ! 
Ubermosh en fait partie ! Outre le titre franchement bizarre, on a là un jeu ultra frénétique. 
Dans la veine d'un Hotline Miami (mais dépouillé de tout aspect narratif), ce shooter en vue de 3/4 consiste à survivre dans une zone pendant 90 secondes contre des hordes de bad guys/aliens.
Le gimmick vraiment sympa du jeu, c'est le clic droit qui permet de dévier les balles adverses. Chopez un flingue, et c'est parti pour le carnage ultime... avant de mourir comme un con xD ! 
On meurt beaucoup et très vite, mais le jeu à un côté addictif super prenant. Les runs sont très courtes, la difficulté va grandissante et la musique nous scotche littéralement à notre clavier et notre souris (sérieux, prenez le en bundle avec l'ost).
En clair, un bon petit jeu pour bien se défouler, qui vous durera une petite poignée d'heures mais qui comble à merveille les petits vides de la vie :D !
Enfin, le jeu à été fait (développement, musique) par une seule personne. Chapeau !

UBERMOSH is a fantastic little game, like a pocket-sized version of something like Nuclear Throne. You may only last a few seconds depending per game (my best score is 101 but generally I'm really bad at this game!) but it always leaves me wanting more. Having "a quick go" on UBERMOSH sometimes leads to an hour or more of me just deparately trying to get a good score. The core mechanics are just so strong and simple that I find it incredibly addictive and genuinely rewarding when I get a decent score.

Speaking of scores, the soundtrack to this game is great heavy stuff that's so much fun to blast monsters to. The sound design in general is really good, the sword and lazer noises are hugely satisfying and I love the announcer voice that plays over the intro.

All in all you're getting an incredibly tightly made, very addicting isometirc shooter for a tiny sum of money. An absolute bargain!

20720523.review:
Presently I am gaming on a low-end PC laptop running Windows 8.1,which is able to run Source games well if I turn the graphics settings down low.

Games likes this shoud be perfect for this computer. However, my FPS goes way down any time the screen gets cluttered with enemies, projectiles, or blood splatters.

That and the "shakey camera" feature that many games utilize in order to make gameplay more immersive and dramatic can make dying in Ubermosh feel cheap sometimes. This is a great looking game with a great soundtrack, and gameplay can be very fun, and I might experience no problems at all if I were running this game on a higher-end machine, but I also feel that games like this mostly cater to casual gamers with lower-end equipment. There's no plot, and the gameplay couldn't be more simple.

While I love the fact that when the battlefield is strewn with the exploded corpses of enemies it looks like a modern-art masterpiece, maybe design a way to turn off some of these mechanics in order to reduce slow-down for people using lower-end (but still relatively new) computers. A radar feature might also help get the jump on enemies that are approaching from areas that are off-screen, to give the player more of an edge against the computer. It feels cheap when your health is low and you path directly into an enemy's projectiles when you didn't know to move or shoot at them because they were off-screen.

While the soundtrack and sound effects are very cool, it'd be great if there were an option to adjust the volume, or turn them off altogether, without muting my computer's speakers.

Right now this is easily a 3/5 game that could be 4/5 with just a little work. 

Fun, great looking, great sounding game, at a good price, despite whatever issues I have.

20718387.review:
This is like a fictional video game prop you saw arcade goers playing in a 1980s sci-fi film.

It starts with a large, gray disco ball and an ominous riff. Then a title screen with some cyberpunk girl. Her hair is as equally fantastic as her giant shoulder pads. Pick a mode and start the game. Morgan Freeman makes an announcement. Something about the colony providing everything, except for violence… and some other stuff. The glorious electronic-punk soundtrack.

Right click swings your giant bullet-reflecting plasma sword. Slice through endlessly spawning enemies. Grab a gun from their peanut butter and jelly corpses that litter the desert floor. Left click shoots. More corpse jam. Grab a better gun. Gunfire is making my sub beg for mercy. Die. A lot. Try different modes. One restricts to sword-play only. One has rapid fire guns. One has the best gun. Die more. Set a high score. Break it. Trade in my high score for Hard Boiled mode. So many more enemies. Mash right mouse button as I wade through the chaos, an ubermosh.

One more time.
One more time.

It's 3 am and I have to go to work in a few hours.

Buy this game. It's just as fun as those kids in the 1980s sci-fi films made it out to be.

20433867.review:
A fast paced top down shooter and slasher, this game is, in a word, fun. Its addicting, easy to learn, hard to master, and just a great indie game. 
 The gameplay is you start with a sword and ricochet projectiles at your enemies by reflecting. The reflected projectile kills your foes instantly, and you cut also rush an enemy and cut them instantly too. A dead enemy always drops a gun you can borrow. Each class you play has a varying amount of lives, and can be orientated towards a shooter or a slasher role. The Warlock starts off with the strongest gun in the game, and can reflect bullets, but also only has 2 lives. The no  mod class/GREEN(The default class) starts with no gun, 4 lives, and can reflect bullets. Kansai starts off with 6 lives, and a sword, but can't grab guns. Gunner has 2 lives and a fully automactic gun, and can make any weapon, even the strongest weapon automactic. 
 Only real problem with this game is a lack of content. Theres a Hardboiled mode, and 4 classes with alternate roles, some Steam achievements, and of course Trading Cards. However, the trading cards really have had their value dropped by a ridiuclous amount($0.24 to now $0.07). If this game had local multiplayer, that would be so amazing...*hint hint game developer*
 To anyone who enjoys addicting fast paced gameplay, I highly recommend this game. Its speed, pumping electric  soundtrack, fast paced action, low price, just mix together to make this one of the best games i've played in a long time.

Что же такое Ubermosh? Это огромный жирный кусок трэша. В нем нет ничего увлекательного и завораживающего. Это игра - пустышка. А теперь по пунктам:

1. Нас ждет ОДНА единственная "арена". Уважаемые разработчики, вы просто представьте, как ей там одиноко...
2. Арена состоит из земли и столбов выросших из земли, окрашенных в цвет земли. Окраска может иметь 3 оттенка, что качественно разнообразит геймплей.
3. ИИ представлен двумя различными видами врагов: Враг 1 и Враг 2. Они кардинально отличаются... Ничем.
4. 3 класса персонажей, которые: либо только юзают катану и имеют 6ХП, либо только стреляют и имеют 3ХП, либо и стреляют и юзают катану и имеют 2ХП. Разнообразие...
5. 4 вида оружия. из которого для 3 включен автоподбор, и это безумно ТУПО. 
6. ДЕРГАЮЩИЙСЯ ЭКРАН во время выстрелов - это просто ... ЗАЧЕМ? 
7. Саундтрек - шлак.

Резюме Игра - мусор. Безоговорочная победа в номинации самых бессмысленных проектов. 
0 из 10.

С уважением, badsapphire, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/steamorators]Ораторы Ste@m[/url].

20390682.review:
Fun and addictive, fast paced, good soundtrack.

Why the negative review?
The game does not feature an options-menu and forces screenshake on.
The game also doesn't lock the mouse-cursor to the game-window due to engine-limitations (you [b]will[/b] frequently click outside the game window and subsequently die, if you have more than 1 monitor).
The hyper-zoom combined with screenshake on every single event also caused me motion-sickness.

Gameplay related complaints:
Projectiles' hit/hurtboxes are way too generous imo, I often find myself getting hit by projectiles that were still at least 1 char width away from me, and this also means you can slice them from midrange.
Feedback for getting hit isn't good enough for tunnel-vision, there's a mild "swoosh" and a pip is removed from your healthbar. Considering this game is sensory overload in every other regard, this feels inconsistent.

TL;DR:
I can not recommend a game that forces screen-shake, can cause motion-sickness and is near unplayable on multi-monitor set-ups, even if I like the basic gameplay (which I do), sorry.

20302287.review:
Very fast, very simple, very tough little game.  Developer wants it to be a shot of adrenaline: success.  There isn't much more to it than that.  Most of the negative reviews boil down to "it's too hard" and that's totally valid.  You'll die a lot because of enemies coming in right above or below giving you very little time to react.  That's a feature, if you'll get frustrated by it, this probably isn't the game for you.  I find it just on the edge of too hard, which is perfect.  Sound track is awesome.

Only played KB + mouse; I can see how control pad would be annoying.  There is no character progression, and a few choices in "classes" which add subtle differences (except Kensai which is crazy hard).  Go forth and die a lot!

You know how sometimes you just want an instantaneous jump into a pit of murder? 

That's what UBERMOSH was made for. 

It's utter simplicity - kill all the things for 90 seconds with your kill beams and a high-frequency blade to metal riffs. It requires quick reflexes, good 360 degree awareness and an appreciation for the GALLON of testosterone that's going to course thorugh your veins after you leave a hundred vaporized, bloody corpses in your wake on a death planet. I reccommend the controller only for the force feedback, so you can truly feel the THUD of the meatiest gorram plasma-doom-bass-cannon I've played with in a while.

I'll just leave it at this: I paid a dollar for the game on sale, and I wish I had bought it at more than full price.

19465657.review:
I really really want to like this game but it still needs work in my opinion. First of all, the good part: The music is great, the art work is decent, the action is fast and fluid and the combo of energy weapons and swords that can deflect projectiles is a  pretty nifty concept (that we've seen before mostly in bullet hell shmups). 

But there is one major issue that really needs to be addressed. The enemy spawning system is too unpredictable and random. There were times that enemies spawned right inside or just outside my field of view shooting me without giving me any chance of deflecting their shots or shooting them down. This plus the weird camera movement and placement (a bit too close at times) makes dodging attacks at times unnecessarily hard. I don't mind a challenge but making the game harder simply by having the enemies spawn completely random and with out restrictions is just cheap and lazy. 

Still, when the game works as it should it's damn good fun. Your weapons feel and sound powerful and killing enemies with them is extremely satisfying almost as much as killing them by deflecting their own bullets. Action is fast paced and fluid, rounds are short and sweet.  

Would I recommend the game to anyone? I'm not really sure to be honest. The price is pretty low, but on the other hand as it is, there's basicaly only one game mode and not much variety. Also the issue with the enemy placement is quite annoying at times. Keep it on your radar for a future purchase. The developers keep patching it consantly, so any possible issues with Ubermosh will be probably ironed out before long.

19329037.review:
Look at the time spent in game of the top reviews.  This is not a deep or lengthy game.  Ubermosh is excessively simple, more a tech demo than a game and not a particularly impressive one at that as the 20 seconds of gameplay in the trailer covers the whole breadth and depth that the game has to offer.

Ubermosh is a top down shoot em up in the vein of Smash TV or Crimsonland.  You run around a fairly barebones arena shooting and/or stabbing a small assortment of guys and monsters, get hit a few times, die, repeat.  And that's it.  There's no unlocks, no story, no levels.  Just shoot, die, repeat until bored.

Ubermosh plays well enough,  The controls are okay on mouse and keyboards.  WASD moves, left click fires a gun, right click swings the sword.  Escape quits back to the menu, no confirmation, no pause menu.  The guns have some punchy sound effects but there's fairly little report of successful hits and nothing when you get hit - which can be very frustrating indeed. 

The screen has a tendency to shake when firing a gun which, when combined with the very close camera, is annoying and disoreinting in the thick of combat

The game lacks an options menu completely so the the repetitive music is overpoweringly loud and the only recourse is to lower the game's volume in windows.  The only options in the game are whether to play on normal or hardboiled (hard mode) and which, if any, class mod you wish to use. 

Class mods add a minimum of variety by limiting what weapons you can use and how many 'respawns' you get (they're not actual respawns, but merely the number of times you can get hit before dying) but the Kensai is the only one that vastly varies the game flow as it removes your ability to use guns, which makes things significantly more difficult.  Reflecting enemy attacks with a sword swing is your only ranged ability and letting them get in close is dangerous, so you'll die a lot to enemies firing so close to you that they're impossible for all but the twitchiest of fingers to reflect.

The rest of the classes consist of getting the best scattergun you can find (there's a total of five-ish ranged weapons in the game), finding a relatively defensible spot, and clicking in every direction to kill enemies before they got on the screen.   You could, I guess only shoot at enemies you can see and stay mobile, but there's little point when the kills just get racked up.  Though the inability to rebind the controls hurts the Kensai class mod, mashing right click is surprisingly less fun than mashing left click.

At any rate, at the end you are either extracted or die.  The game over screen, such that is is, is very simple and incredibly abrupt.  It is often quite difficult to discern what exactly killed you because one moment you're dodging, shooting, and stabbing and the rest you're staring at a mostly black screen telling you you're out of respawns.  There are no death animations, not even a death sound.  Immediate cut to black and then back to the main menu.

Ubermosh describes itself as 'Cyberpunk,' or at least a lot of people think that it is.  But there's no real cyberpunk to it.  The main menu aesthetic fits the bill, but everything else exudes a more post-apocalyptic vibe.  Were I cynical I'd say that the cyberpunkish window dressing may have been chasing a fad.

At the end of the day, or more accurately the hour Ubermosh takes to lose its charm, you're left with a simple shooter that pales in comparison to dozens of other similar titles on steam and the tremendous praise it is receiving is mind boggling.  Don't waste your money, save up for Crimsonland or Nation Red instead.

19315883.review:
Absolutely zero substance to this game. After playing for 5 minutes you end up seeing all there is to see and are able to reach 100% completion in less than an hour. Wave after wave of enemies spawn with no more variety than the standard four types of enemies in the game with absolutely no reward in sight save for a personal high score without even an online leaderboard. No challenge, unlockables or progression to justify playing this for more than a few minutes at a time. There is no replay value to be had.
Don't understand why the majority of reviews are positive either. Maybe it's the soundtrack? IMO I found it to be really bland and boring, but maybe people are able to look past the fact that this game has literally no content to speak of as long as they have some adrenaline pumping 250bpm tracks looping in the background.

Go purchase Nuclear Throne or wait until this is inevitably one of those $0.14 games on sale in the future.

19184026.review:
"UBERMOSH is an arcade game about cutting bullets with a sword, in a gun-filled cyberpunk mosh pit."

Sounds great right? I thought the same, I bought the game when it was in Early-Access to support the dev, after a couple of months it jumped from version 0.2 to full release (if I remember correctly) so I decided to play but I got bored too fast after playing for a couple of minutes because there's no content in this game at all.

Pros

+ A couple of minutes of fun shooting/slicing enemies
+ Random level generation
+ Nice 2D isometric graphics & art-style
+ Good soundtrack
+ Would run on a toaster

Cons

- No perks/skills/power-ups, etc.
- Random level generation is very bland
- Lack of Map/Enemy/Weapon variety
- Lack of content
- No replay value (You can tell that by looking to those who have recommended the game, they hardly have more than 2-3 hours of gameplay)
- Camera shakes are horrible, could lead to motion sickness

"UBERMOSH was made to give you a shot of adrenaline in a couple of minutes."

So if you enjoy fast paced arcade games with no content then this would be fun for a short time, but if you are looking for a high replay-value game then look elsewhere.

I feel ripped off
I'm a big fan of cyberpunk games, which makes me feel like this game took advantage of that by marketing it's self as such without any cyberpunk themes or visuals. I played this game for about 10 minutes and then had to ask myself "Is that it, did i pay money for this?" so i played it for another 10 and then concluded "yep that's it, you paid money for this."
 
Style over substance can work, especially in casual games, but it's really not done right here with it's lack of substance. No story, too many unanswerd basic questions like who am i, who am i fighting, and why. and overall just felt like an excuse to mkae a game with "cool graphics, and awesome music" neither of which i'd write home about.

My biggest complaint is that the actual gameplay feels unfair, hit ditection is too leanient, Enemies don't give you any elbow room, swarm you from every direction, screen centers on your mouse leading to cheep deaths when you round a corner without enough room to see enemies coming, and overall it feel "slippery". 

4/10 Too frustrating for casuals, not substaial enough for hardcores.

Highly recommended. Short game about good old ultra-violence. 2d top-down-view arena bullet-hell (shooter) genre, which is well-known for the games like Crimsonland. Ubermosh have its own nice feature, which is working just like in the Star Wars - you have a sword to reflect enemy shots back to them. Offers quite a challenge, of the basic kind - kill as many frags as possible before they catch you... or the timer beeps off.

As a minus, it is very short - if you are a skilled Crimsonland veteran, I'm sure, you can beat it for all achievements in less than one hour. Also, there are not so much variety in guns, gore and types of enemies, as you may expect.

Still, the experience is nice, the price now is very affordable, and to the top of all, all steam cards are so valuable, so you can return all your money spended, and possibly get some extra money over the price you've paid!

Mark 8/10 - best buy, if discounted. Tiny-sized, yet very exciting - if you have a knack for quick-paced bullethell bloodbaths.

PS If you're aiming to the gold with all achievements, there is one where you supposed to survive to the end of round, 7 times. It is not impossible, but it goes that way that you either getting the top score, or not rushing into battle and survive. So! To get that "survival" badge, I suggest using the warlock setting, where you have the best gun from the start. Just find a place where you'll be covered from 2 sides, and shoot in other directions. With some luck, they'll not touch you until the timer is off.

18083988.review:
UBERMOSH is a fun, but very little title. Basically it's a twin stick shooter with an arcade/arena style. You're nameless character (probably the woman in the title menu) gets send on a planet to wreck every single thing that comes to you. And they all come with guns. Story doesn't really exist in this game, goal is to survive as long as possible (a round, which lasts 90 seconds) while at the same time killing as much enemies as possible.  There are 3 options to kill enemies:

1, Shoot them
2, Cut them up with your sword
3, Deflect their bullets back with your sword

As for number 1, there are a total of four guns in the game, 3 weapons that kinda get the job done and the 6 Shot Lasergun, that is so good that your character won't pick up any other weapon.

As for number 2, this option isn't really that recommended, as enemies usually only fire when very very close usually and this ends up losing one Respawn point, which are basically Health Points, or "Tries" in this case.

Number 3 is very interesting and can make the game pretty tricky, as you can combine Shooting enemies and deflecting bullets at the same time.

These 3 methods are part of the game and it's game modifications, which there are 4 of. You have the normal mode, a sword only mode which tests your skill in parrying Bullets, a Autofire gun mode that takes away your sword und reduces your Health points and a mode that starts you with the best weapon but you get the least amount of Health possible.
For each Mod you get a Medal in the main title screen if you manage to kill 150 enemies in time.

I really liked the inclusion of these mods, as they do keep the game interesting, especially the Sword only Mod was pretty difficult at parts and it took me many retrys to finally rack up 150 kills in it.

Because this game is difficult. And you will die. Alot. Taking things like a constant shaking camera everytime you fire (which is pretty annoying after a while) and a sometimes frustrating camera (meaning you can not always see the enemies coming, causing you to run into them alot of times) aside, these guys come in masses. If you are not skilled with your sword and parrying, good luck dodging those bullets. On the Hard Boiled Option (changeable in the main menu right from the get go) you can also make more enemies spawn at once, which can make things even more tricky to handle.

The graphics are nice for what they are, i personally disliked that the maps are all basically the same design, a moon desert, where each time just the layout changes. A bit of variety in design would have been pretty cool for this game. Same goes for the music. Every stage has a different song, but that doesn't mean much when every song sounds basically the same. The lack of  guns and good use of them was also a bit sad to see.

Overall i would say this game is ok. For a price of 4-5 bucks it is way too short and lacks the depth, length and variety that makes it truly stand out or interesting for a long while. If you got all the achievements you have basically seen everything the game has to offer really. If it is in sale though and you want a short, but nice little game, go ahead and purchase this.

18047037.review:
By the time I was a kid arcades were becoming a thing of the past, if they weren't a thing of the past already. Growing up in the late 1990's meant that I was too young to experience the great communal arcade halls of legend so I had to seek shelter in every bowling alley, movie theater, and smoke filled restaurant closet in existence that held the remaining, publicly available, arcade games. As a small child, you had to risk life and limb, talking to the creepy middle aged guy behind the counter who's slightly balding, but still tries to work a mullet, so he can take you to a bizarre David Lynch inspired 'back room' with one Centipede cabinet underneath a lone flickering light bulb. Yes, I might have been scared for my life, but I'll be damned if I didn't spend hours behind that joystick, trying to beat the high score of every horny trucker, pot head and divorcee who bothered to play that machine. Fast forward to 2015 and I'm not entirely certain if those rooms exist any more, but if they did, Ubermosh would be an insanely popular hit.

The concept of this game is simple; the world has become so pure that the only form of entertainment people can gain is from violence. The players one goal is to fight their way out of a Hunger Games-like colosseum. This is as much story and canon that the developer, Walter Machado, gives you and I suppose that is all you really need.

Before I begin nitpicking the ins and outs of Ubermosh, let me make this incredibly clear, THIS IS A FUN GAME. The gameplay itself is condensed enough for anyone to understand and pick up and play in quick doses, just like a traditional arcade game. You get thrown into a top down bullet hell shooter with a sword that can reflect/cut through bullets and are forced to survive giant waves of bizarre enemies for about 90 seconds. This game sounds and looks like it was taken from the pages of a rejected John Carpenter screenplay from the 80's in the vein of Big Trouble In Little China, and the better it is for it. The weirder and more difficult Ubermosh gets, the more fun it is to play but this is where my biggest complaint comes to light; the game doesn't evolve much, if at all, from its initial concept.

To start with, the controls of this game are very tight. The response time is incredibly fast and there is just a touch of momentum added to the movement in order to make running feel weighted. That style of movement is very important to keep in mind when engaging in all sorts of combat because there is a small amount of delay when using your weapons in order to prevent spamming it. While some people might take issue with this, I thought it was a nice attempt to balance the combat with the multitude of guns you are bound to pick up through the course of your many playthroughs.

And through using the multitude of guns that you pick off the dead carcasses of your enemies, you have to survive screens filled with aliens all trying to kill you. After I initially launched the game, it took me a solid 20 minutes of repeatedly banging my head into my keyboard before I could last 30 seconds if I was lucky. My perseverance ended up paying off for me because, in the end, my biggest run ended in a score of 169, and I'm still too proud of myself to reset my score in hardcore mode and loose what I worked so hard to achieve. While going on runs that end with beating your high score feels so fantastic, the more runs you go on, the purely skeletal structure of the game reveals itself.

This game could benefit from so much. For example, a larger selection of characters to choose from could add so much depth, adding a screen clearing ultimate ability for the one character you have could turn the tide of so many battles, and taking a minute to create load outs for each run you take can add a certain level of basic strategy, just to name a few. The reason I point these aspects out in particular is because I feel everything needed to add these mechanics is already in the game, but their absence makes the game feel disappointingly empty. Of course, the hope is that additional layers will be added in future updates, as long as Walter Machado continues to support his solid game, but there hasn't been any updates of note made at the time of this review.

For the purpose of covering all bases here, I do have to make a remark on the graphics. If I haven't hinted at it already, this game looks like the love child of the cover from REO Speedwagon's Hi-Infedelity and Joss Whedon's Serenity. The actual gameplay is built in your typical “Insert Number Here-Bit” style of almost every indie game out there today, but the menu art and character portrait are very well done with a lot of bright colors thrown all over the place. If this game existed in an arcade cabinet form, it would belong in the corner next to the bathroom of a seedy underground night club with flashy strobe lights where everyone wears neon glow sticks and does cocaine, or a laser tag arena. In a stylistic sense, Ubermosh achieves what it is trying to pull off, and pulls it off well.

So, without any further ado...

(T)oo (L)ong; (D)idn't (R)ead : While built on a rock hard foundation of solid mechanics and masochistically addictive game-play, Ubermosh offers little more than its neon drenched looks.

18036055.review:
Ubermosh is a fast-paced arcade-style game with a cyberpunk setting.

It's easy to learn, but possessed of a high difficulty, partly due to how frantic the action gets but also due to a few unfortunate design choices.

Pros:
- Games are fast, lasting at most 90 seconds. This makes it ideal for killing a little time.
- Simple controls. Move with W,A,S and D, shoot with your left-click and melee with your right-click. It is configured for gamepads as well but I personally haven't felt the need to try.
- Different character configurations grant some replayability.
- Weapon effects are colorful and feel like they would indeed vaporize your foes.

Cons
- The game suffers from some artificial difficulty. Enemies may spawn right on top of you and fire before you can react.
- The screen-shaking effect caused by firing weapons or taking a hit. I get what the developer was going for, and I do appreciate that, but it becomes a hinderance when you start taking hits because your eyes can't keep up with the frantic action coupled with the shaking screen.
- The camera can be your worst enemy. It follows your reticle a bit, but that makes it easy for enemies to move in behind you while you're trying to get a shot in the other direction. I also feel that there is never enough of a view at the bottom of the screen, and find myself firing blindly when moving in that direction so that I'm less likely to get surprised. That takes away the feeling that I'm skillfully fending off waves of enemies and leaves me feeling like I'm just spraying and praying.
- The arenas don't really have any sense of variance. Flat ground with random squarish blocks for cover. At least a few different textures for visual appeal would be nice, but generally everything is brown on brown.
- The weapons suffer from a lack of variety. It would be nice for them to handle differently so that each player could develop their own preference, but the fact is that there's no reason to not immediately try to grab the 'best gun' since it has a huge spread and is just as lethal as the rest.

All these things considered, I do enjoy the game and feel that it is worth buying, but maybe try to get it during a sale, when it's common to see it at 50% off, and may as well get the soundtrack while you're at it.

17947002.review:
Ein wirklich super Game!
Man hat hier natürlich nicht viel Content außer 4 Klassen und eine Arena mit ca. 5 versch. Gegnertypen und ich glaub ca. genau so viele unterschiedliche Feuerwaffen plus ein Schwert (außer bei einer Klasse).

Warum sollte es dann ein "super Game" sein fragt sich der ein oder andere vielleicht und das will ich euch direkt beantworten.
Dieser "Arenashooter" pusht echt euer Adrenalin und verbessert effektiv eure Reflexe.
Wer gerne FirstPerson-Shooter spielt wie z.B. CounterStrike kann sich wirklich gut mit UBERMOSH aufblasen um dann inGame bessere Reflexe zu haben und durch ein gewisses Adrenalin-Level schonmal etwas gehyped zu sein.
Das sind viele Fremdworte aber Betreffende werden wissen was ich meine. ;)

Für alle anderen die nix mit FPS am Hut haben kann ich es aber auch empfehlen denn durch das schnelle, reflexlastige Gameplay kann man sich generell für ein paar kurze Spiele zwischendurch immer wieder begeistern und wirkt nach einer Partie meiner Auffassung nach auch entschieden wacher als vorher.
Dazu trägt auch eine wirklich stimmige Musik bei welche das Gameplay noch unterstützt.

Auch grafisch erwartet euch eine sehr hübsche Pixelgrafik in einer Cyberpunk-Welt ohne großen Storyhintergrund aber da kann man seiner Fantasie freien lauf lassen und ggf. nebenher einen 80er Jahre Sci-Fi-Film laufen lassen. ;)
Die Mechanik ist einfach aber vorallem sehr gut ausbalanciert. Man hat zu keiner Zeit das Gefühl aufgrund hakeliger Steuerung oder unfairer Gegner zu sterben.
Das macht den Wiederspielfaktor sehr hoch, da man doch sehr ehrgeizig eigene Fehler schnell erkennt und es im nächsten Match besser machen möchte und mehr Punkte sammeln will.
Da die Matches so schön schnell gehen, versucht man es immer und immer wieder aufs Neue und selbst Spieler die sonst nie was mit Highscores zu tun hatten (wie ich) werden hier immer ein neues Glücksgefühl haben wenn man seinen alten Punktestand bricht.

Preis/Leistung ist mehr als in Ordnung für das Game denn hier macht nicht der Content sondern das Spielgefühl und der Spaß beim Schnetzeln und Kugeln mit dem Schwert abwehren einfach den ausschlaggebenden Punkt aus.

Für alle Indiefreunde der schnellen Unterhaltung ein MUSS! ;)

17751194.review:
Fast-paced retro arcade bullet-hellesque bullet deflecting goodness.

I initially started out with the controller and eventually moved onto the keyboard+mouse. It's personal preference really as it is very easily playable with either control scheme.

As far as the action goes: it's blindingly fast and crushingly addictive. Different enemies handle different weapons which determine size, speed, and spread of the bullets. To fight them, our means of attack are your gun and sword; the latter can also be used for defense as it can deflect bullets.

With the ability to deflect bullets, there is also the added variation in how bullets are deflected; for example, the large single bullet is deflected into two slower bullets, while the bullets from the game's proclaimed 'best weapon' almost appears to move back at the same number and at the same speed. A nice feature is the ability to control the direction of the deflected projectiles depending on where you have hit them.

There's not too much difference between enemies. There seem to be three total but they really only come in two sizes: humanoid, and large alien size. Despite this all seem to move the same speed. While that may sound boring, I believe it simplifies things and helps add to the twitch-frantic action.

As hard as this game is, you don't ever really feel cheated and are forced to 'git gud'.

As far as visuals go, the masterpiece is the pictured soldier on the menu. The art style and symbols used remind me very much of Tsutomu Nihei - it's good stuff. I also liked the fact that as you survived and progressed and raised your ranking, the soldier's armour would change (both in game and on the menu) and reflect that change in rank; though I wish you could view and choose the different armour variants.

For $4USD, this is a great arcade-style game with an awesome soundtrack too.

PS: The 'Kensai Mastery' is impossible.

28/08/15: Kensai High Score = 114 -_-

17704526.review:
I've played many an arcade-style shooter before.

I've even played ones where you can deflect bullets, ones with great soundtracks, and ones with perfected gameplay.

Never, however, have I met one before that encompassed all of these aspects so well. From the head-pounding soundtrack to the heart-pounding action, bare screen pixels' worth of difference between sudden death and violent, scream-yourself-hoarse glory, UBERMOSH is where it's at and UBERMOSH is where it will stay.

I'm making this review coming off a survived-3-events streak on Warlock. If I had never picked up this game, I would never have known what I was missing.

My only, sole complaint is that my reactions aren't fast enough to play on Kensai.

Seriously. Buy this game. It's not just worth it: this is a genuine diamond of frantic arcade action.

17594893.review:
[b]August 18, 2015[/b]
UBERMOSH is around version 0.02 of a finalized game, even by the listed patch notes. That full game could be awesome, but this is just 90-second snips of a trash arena. Lacking in graphics and variety, the solid combat isn't enough to justify multiple dollars and barely hours of gameplay.

Story time: I picked up UBERMOSH early in development, mostly because I was one of many that got Gearcrack Arena for around $0.09 USD with a coupon. It was weird, confusing, obtuse, and somehow deeper than UBERMOSH. Reaching level 3 in Gearcrack Arena was quite a feat, mostly because the controls were so confusing. The music was great at least, and worthwhile for nine cents, so I jumped on UBERMOSH with the hopes that Walter Machado would improve. The core gameplay was improved and actually worked really well. However, UBERMOSH still has the content variety of a tech demo, and feels like a test for something bigger.

There are a few issues at play that are forcing me to restrict my recommendation. Firstly, the Gearcrack Arena game I mentioned is no longer on Steam. It turns out that Walter Machado stated somewhere that Gearcrack Arena was only a year-long experiment (for sale), and after that year, he removed the game completely. There's no store page to confirm if this was stated to customers, and I don't recall any notice of the game having time-limited availability. Owners can still download the game, but bugs and issues will never be fixed. I can't confirm the dates, but it seems like the game disappeared after Steam Refunds were enabled. Walter Machado doesn't seem like a bad developer, but I have to worry. There's no real reason to remove the game, other than not bothering to fix it. If it was intended to be a temporary trial, release it for free. 

Ignoring concerns of shady behavior, UBERMOSH is just too shallow. Arena generation is hard to notice, as the environment is just a big square with random blocks of brown walls. Enemies and guns are varied but feel the same. Class mods are just challenges imposed for a specific playstyle. The hitboxes feel very large, reflecting bullets 10 feet from your sword and getting hit from 3 feet away. After a few 90-second rounds, you've seen everything. 

UBERMOSH can be fun for a bit, and has great potential. The shooting and swordplay feels great, but it needs a full game behind it. I was eagerly watching patch notes, and immensely disappointed to see the game go from version 0.014 or so to "Final" by adding cards. It's an alpha still. Walter Machado's games have charmed me, and I want them to be great. But this isn't finished, final, or even worth a few dollars currently. Although he may suddenly remove the game when he starts the next one, I really can't recommend UBERMOSH until it has more than 90 seconds of neon on brown.

With a katana in your hand, you are thrown into a desert arena, with hordes of enemies pouring onto you, expected to fight for your life. You cut down your enemies, pick up their weapons and use those to kill them. Your katana is not only a weapon, but also your defense, as it can deflect bullets. You have only 4 "respawns", which is the amount of times you can get shot before having to teleport away.

The game combines a nice cyberpunk aesthetic with tight controls, and a nice soundtrack. The gameplay is extended with a "hardboiled mode" which reduces the amount of respawns you have, as well as "gun mods" which change your gameplay. Give up half your respawns in exchange for starting with the best gun, or have double respawns but only use your katana.

The game isn't very long, but it is really enjoyable. I'd certainly recommend it at this price.

I'm sad to say that I cannot recommend this game in its current state. 

Pros:

-A name I could get behind

Cons:

-Lacking map variety

I will say I like the game's initial concept. Running around deflecting bullets in a Smash TV style top-down Shooter like a pixel-Jedi is pretty awesome, there's just nothing here to support it, and plenty of aggrivating/nauxiating design mistakes.

Pros:
Solid mouse and keyboard controls
Slicing enemy fire is fun
Slick graphics
"Class Mods" add some replay

Cons:
Screen shake is overdone and nauxiating.
No story or context
Only a handful of arenas
Only a handful of enemy types
Really poor X-Box 360 controller support with unbearably loose aiming reticle on the right stick and attack buttons on the left shoulders instead of the right, with no ability to remap.

It has the potential to get better if the Dev is willing to put more work into it, but given that it has launched with a full release, I don't see much more being added.

Games with single-person development teams have done better.

17529395.review:
Ubermosh is an immediate, punchy, addictive arcade thrill. You have a sword. Your enemies have guns. Your sword doesn't just cut people - it also cuts bullets, redirecting them back towards where they came from. So you slice an enemy and take his gun, and then you shoot and slice until either you've succumbed to the increasing numbers of enemies spawning in or you manage to survive for 90 seconds. Then you start again.

It sounds simple because it IS simple, but that simplicity is in no way to its detriment. UBERMOSH may have a limited scope, but within that scope it's pretty much functionally perfect. That rapid gameplay loop - spawn in, kill, die, restart - proves immensely satisfying, recalling games like Hotline Miami and Luftrausers in its immediacy. Extra wrinkles are added by class mods that place limitations on your loadout and an extra-tough Hardboiled game mode.

It's not the prettiest game in the world, but personally I like the bleary-eyed, neon-lit 80's VHS presentation, and the colourful pools of alien blood that soon decorate the arena floor add some much-needed brightness. The music is spot-on, adding immensely to the sense of pace and urgency.  You can play using mouse and keyboard or twin-stick style with a gamepad, although personally I found myself preferring a hybrid control method where I aimed using the mouse and moved around using a controller balanced on my knee; it sounds unwieldy, but it's how I got my highest scores and survived the 90 seconds for the first time.

I can't see many people playing UBERMOSH for long periods at a time, but then that's not really what it was made for. I've been having sessions of about fifteen minutes, and what's notable about that is that it always feels like I've been playing for longer, which I think is a pretty good recommendation. With its chunky pixels, copious amounts of screen-shake and immensely satisfying gameplay, UBERMOSH feels like the best game Vlambeer never made, and I can't think of a much higher complement for an arcade shooter than that.

17464313.review: Ubermosh is a quick game for players who like frenetic games and screen-shake. Each game session is at most 90 seconds in a hostile environment full of aliens. It is the second journey of the indie lonewolf Walter Machado, who evolves his skills as a developer with every game he makes. Ubermosh delivers a fantastic mechanic, where the player is able to cut the enemy's bullets and thus kill more enemies. In addition, some weapons complete what you can do with the character. The game has a very 90's vibe with a sovereign Cologne in the sky where the game takes place. The music is amazing and makes a perfect match with the frenetic pace of the game. The game has some issues due to being developed by just one guy. It would be interesting if there were a lot more of content, different scenarios, a sense of progression. For me the ideal would be a roguelike with elements that would make each of the 90 seconds different from each other. The achievementes could also be better used in the game. Nevertheless, the price it's being sold is very fair for the casual fun that the game delivers.

17344903.review:
Ubermosh is very simple but elegant in its design. You have exactly 90 seconds to destroy as many of your enemies as possible and of course not die in the process. This game is all about fast replay, like arcade games of yesteryear. Armed with a sword you will dance across the battlefield weaving death while using your enemies weapons against them. For an EA title this all works very well and and the controls feel very tight. As far as difficulty goes, Ubermosh is far from an easy game but death doesn't feel cheating usually, unless an enemy teleports on top of you. One thing to keep in mind though is that you pay for what you get here. While the visuals, music, and gameplay of Ubermosh are fantastic. It's short, repetitive and mostly involves killing everything in sight. Beating your own score is all that is currently involved in the game. Hopefully leaderboards and more features to shake things up a little are on the way. (Bosses would be sweet.) If you are the type of person who played Flash games for hours trying to top leaderboards or you enjoy games where you slaughter endlessly. Ubermosh is going to satisfy. Those looking for something more complex and feature rich, may be disappointed. So get your twitch fingers ready and sharpen those eyes and play some Ubermosh!

I made a video preview to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/ii2Toy60H5U
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

17327028.review:
This game offers two things in spades:
1. Action
2. Simplicity

The music is great. Simple and effective, action packed tunes. The controls are responsive and about as "pick up and play" as you can get.

Many games have good reviews with long hours of gameplay. This game's strength lays in the fact that you don't have to play it long to have a great experience. There's so much action packed into every minute, you don't need to play long hours to get the most out of the game. That being said, I can see myself putting in more time in the future because of the high difficulty and replayability. 

In short: if you want a game that offers a huge blast of action in a very short period of time, this is the game for you!

[b]UBERMOSH[/b] é um jogo brasileiro que une ação frenética com uma trilha sonora divertida que acompanha bem o ritmo das batalhas. Você tem 90 segundos para matar o máximo de inimigos possíveis, atirando neles ou rebatendo os tiros adversários.

O jogo atualmente está em [b]Early Acess[/b] e conta com um sistema de classes (apesar de fraco e pouco explorado ainda) bem interessante, são 3 classes: Kensai, Gunner e Warlock (que é minha favorita).

Apesar disso, na minha opinião, acho que falta algumas coisinhas para deixar o jogo mais ''durável'' (e serve até de sugestão), coisas como: Mais classes, mais mapas, mais armas, modos alternativos além do comum 90 segundos, powerups, melhoria no desempenho do jogo, leaderboards etc... mas enfim, acho que é só questão de tempo para que entre em pauta essas questões no desenvolvimento do jogo.

De qualquer forma, peço de antemão que os desenvolvedores não larguem o projeto. Eu, particularmente, vejo grande potencial no jogo.

16586940.review:
UPDATE 0.011
What can I say?
No early access game, for me, has shown as much potential as this one. I can't wait until development goes further, and we get new gamemodes and such. The game feels amazingly smooth, and though I disapprove of controllers for this genre of game, I found the control scheme tight and well programmed.
The awesome feeling you get when you kill tons of enemies with one shot, or one bullet slice is unrivalled in the market right now.
For a game so cheap, this is the intense action I know you crave.

My one problem is the difficulty.

The game has two difficulties, and I got Blade Saint on both before I had hit the half an hour timer. I know this will be improved in further updates, as it is just early access, but I needed at least one criticism. This is a review, not free advertisement.

UPDATE 0.012
The game is running slower, there are constant graphical glitches and I'm having trouble with lag when you change weapon. A game which was working so well has been set back by one update. I'm still going to recommend it, because I believe that the developer can pull it out of this laggy, glitchy update.

16243964.review:
UBERMOSH is a fast-paced cyberpunk action game that is currently available through Steam Early Access. In UBERMOSH you get thrown into a mosh pit full of crazy enemies armed to the teeth and you have to use your katana to cut the bullets up and send them back to where they came from! Killing enemies lets you pick up their guns so you can bring down fire upon your enemies from your own weapons too!

Since UBERMOSH is in Early Access and is also extremely cheap I won't mention anything along the lines of 'lack of content' in my Early Access review.

+Awesome pixel art style
+A kickass soundtrack
+Well designed enemies and weapons
+The weapons that are currently available are varied so you get a lot of different types of projectiles flying all over the place
+Each round is ninety seconds (not that you'll ever make it to ninety seconds) so it's possible to have a couple of quick games even if you're short on time
+Excellent value for money even if you only play it for an hour since it has such a low price
+Simple controls (KB&M)
+Provides a good challenge but the more you play the better you get, at least that's what I found
+Three playable classes have been introduced, they add new playstyles to the game but there is still the no-class mode which is what the game was pre-update

-I don't see you being able to play for more than an hour or two but for the price that isn't too bad

Here's a short gameplay video I recorded:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DwkeOsMvkow

Verdict:
Essential Purchase (9/10)

UBERMOSH is a fantastic, fast-paced action game with a cool cyberpunk style, awesome pixel graphics, a fantastic soundtrack and great value for money. If you still haven't picked this game up then you're doing yourself a disservice.

[i]No drama, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/justreviews]Just Reviews[/url]?[/i]

El K.

that's about it for UBERMOSH atm. I am looking forward to updates.
